American service isn’t limited to just picking up a rifle to defend our democracy. Service also means picking up a soup spoon to feed the less fortunate, a piece of chalk to teach low-income kids or a hammer to rebuild a home destroyed by a wildfire.

To help fix this problem&protect the 1.5 million jobs the Great Lakes support, @SenatorDurbin&I introduced legislation to ban discharges of untreated sewage into the Great Lakes, provide funding for cleanup efforts&help ensure our water is clean throughout the Great Lakes region

Roughly 22 billion gallons of untreated sewage and storm water are discharged into the Great Lakes each year, threatening the health and livelihoods of the tens of millions of Americans who depend on it as their source for drinking water.

ICYMI: Our country can never repay the debt we owe our Veterans, but it’s on us to try. It’s on us to make sure we don’t just salute them on Veterans Day, but honor them on the other 364 days of the year, too:  https://www.military.com/daily-news/2018/11/11/i-owe-my-life-warrior-ethos-my-fellow-troops.html/amp …

I was quite literally in pieces, but my buddies risked their lives and refused to leave me behind. Every day I think about what they did for me and what I can do to repay them. Making sure I don’t let them down is what drives me to do everything I can for our Veterans and troops.

Today is my Alive Day, the anniversary of the day I almost died but didn’t. On this day 14 years ago, an RPG tore through the cockpit of the helicopter I was flying over Iraq, taking my legs and partial use of my right arm with it.

After today’s ceremony, I was also able to present Mike Scheidt, the grandson of a brave American hero that served in WWII, with a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star that his late grandfather Francis earned for his sacrifice and valor in uniform pic.twitter.com/YyDy8iTrZF

To each of them, to all my fellow Veterans and all of their families, thank you from the bottom of my heart for your service and sacrifice. God bless you, God bless our troops in harm’s way today and God bless the United States of America.

It’s time we build on the foundation the Higher Education Act created and pass legislation like the America’s College Promise Act and make higher education more affordable for all.
I put myself through college with student loans, grants, and waitressing and I’m still paying off my student loans today. The cost of higher education is unattainable and unreasonable.
43 years ago today the Higher Education Act was signed into law, giving millions of Americans financial assistance and opening the opportunity for students to follow their dreams and passions.

But only one man controls whether I, and my colleagues, will get a chance to vote. That is the Senate Majority Leader. He doesn’t have to vote yes on these bills, but I hope he will do the right thing in simply allowing us to finally debate and vote on these life-saving measures.
We can do all these things and in the process, we will also strengthen the Second Amendment by making sure only law-abiding Americans can legally purchase a firearm.
It also includes voting yes on strengthening penalties for illegal firearms trafficking, lying on federal forms and closing absurd loopholes in the law.
This includes voting yes to expand the coverage of background checks, improve the NICS system, make it more difficult for dangerous individuals to obtain firearms and outlaw weapons of war.
Commonsense bills to end this sort of violence are already written. I am ready to vote to pass them today, tomorrow, whenever.
